TitleBlock: VSCM 100  Computer Imaging I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores current potentials, limitations, and issues related to use of computer software for design applications.  Projects include graphics creation and manipulation; image acquisition, creation and manipulation; text creation and manipulation; typography; input and output options and control; hardware/software/system fundamentals; and troubleshooting.

TitleBlock: VSCM 140  Calligraphy 0.0-3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers the skills and understanding of letterforms as geometry and type, development of hand/eye skill in letter-forming, investigation of solids and voids, and use of traditional and modern tools and materials. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 200  Computer Imaging II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides continued study of electronic imaging with emphasis on Graphic Design process for print and screen design.

TitleBlock: VSCM 230  Visual Communication I 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides an overview of graphic design as an applied art. Covers the given, the formal, and the psychological aspects of graphic design.

TitleBlock: VSCM 231  Visual Communication II 0.0-4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Continues VSCM 230. Covers corporate identity and explores logo development using the pictoral mark, typographic solution, and abstract interpretation as symbols of identity.

TitleBlock: VSCM 232  Visual Communication III 0.0-4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Examines problems in graphic design on the relationship between designer and client, including solving specific situations of image-making with emphasis on the total identity of an organization, firm, or publication. Involves extensive exploration of color and imagery. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 240  Typography I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Uses the history of type as the backdrop for the introduction to the art and craft of conventional through state-of-the-art typesetting as well as the creative and extraordinary use of type. Focuses on the letter, word, and sentence. Studio/lecture.

TitleBlock: VSCM 241  Production 0.0-3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers traditional and electronic means of print production. Explores alternate means of production and various printing and output methods. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 242  Typography II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Continues VSCM 240. Broadens the scope to deal with the paragraph and the typeset page, with increased attention to the importance of subtleties and refinements. Explores the differing requirements of type in relationship to pictorial images.

TitleBlock: VSCM 247  On Screen Typography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course develops a visual sensitivity to typographical compositions on screen while expanding knowledge of current technologies.

TitleBlock: VSCM 330  Visual Communication IV 0.0-4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Examines problems in information graphics, including signage, environmental graphic design, and exhibit design. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 331  Visual Communication V 0.0-4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Focuses on techniques and methods of advanced problem solving. Through a series of three projects, the student learns to analyze conceptual and contextual relationships pertinent to any visual communication assignment. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 332  Visual Communication IV 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on techniques and methods of advanced problem solving and exploration of extended identity systems. Students learn to analyze conceptual and contextual relationships pertinent to any visual communication assignment.

TitleBlock: VSCM 333  Visual Communication V 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on information graphics, including signage, environmental graphic design, and exhibit design. Information graphics are graphic visual representations of information, data or knowledge. These graphics present complex information quickly and clearly. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 340  Typography III 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Typography III concentrates on the exploration and management of large blocks of text in specific design problems. Special emphasis will be placed on the style and readability of typographic treatments.

TitleBlock: VSCM 345  IKI: Tamagawa-Drexel Exchange 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The 12-day program is open to all University students and entails a collaboration between Drexel students and Tamagawa students in Japan as well as at Drexel (Philadelphia).    In Japan, students will survey and experience the true Japan by visiting exceptional sites that exemplify the old and the new world of Japanese culture and life. The trip will balance visits between the everyday/industries and cultural sites/museums to capture a comprehensive understanding of the Japanese “IKI.”    In Philadelphia, each group (made of Tamagawa and Drexel students) will conduct on-site research in historical and cultural venues and neighborhoods. Students will learn about immigration history, changing cultures over generations, and the challenges that diverse communities face.

TitleBlock: VSCM 350   [WI] Graphic Design: 20th Century and Beyond 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Concentrates on impact and significance of the graphic design profession in society through the history and movements of the profession and the work of 20th-century masters of visual communication.  Students will analyze conceptual and contextual relationships and develop greater awareness of stylistic content and its relevance to the culture. This is a writing intensive course.

TitleBlock: VSCM 360  Design on Site 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Weekly visits to studios of various design disciplines such as small graphic design offices, environmental graphic design firms, advertising agencies, book and magazine publishers, and website developers.  A written report is due at the end of the term.

TitleBlock: VSCM 370  Experimental Publication Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course concentrates on exploring alternative formats and unique delivery systems for the transfer of information. Special emphasis is placed on developing appropriate imagery for the defined readership, formatting, the use of a comprehensive grid system and the development of a wayfinding system for the publication. The course will build a greater awareness of proportion, readability and information transfer, and will reinforce the use of color as a visual communication tool.

TitleBlock: VSCM 399  Independent Study in Graphic Design 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides individualized study in graphic design in a specialized area of study.  May be repeated for credit. Department permission required.

TitleBlock: VSCM 430  Visual Communication VI 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Continues VSCM 331. Explores three-dimensional graphic design processes and techniques for communication, including problems of scale, material, form, and function. Emphasizes package design. Includes point-of-purchase design. Studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 440  Book Design 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Investigates design of books, from their pre-Gutenberg origins to contemporary technology of design, binding, paper, and finishing. Includes multiple page formats, production grids, and sequential images. Lecture/studio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 450  Professional Portfolio 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Focuses on the preparation of a professional Graphic Design portfolio.  A critical process that includes the screening of completed projects, reworking or expanding projects, and reconstructing/creating final portfolio components.   A formal interview presentation of the portfolio is also explored and refined.

TitleBlock: VSCM 455  Electronic Portfolio 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Focuses on the design and production of a web based Graphic Design portfolio using web graphics and imagery through visuals, motion and sound within the software programs of Dreamweaver & Flash.

TitleBlock: VSCM 460  Professional Practice 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers running a design office, including basic contracts, fee structures, and the design process. Explores types of design offices; working with suppliers, printers, photographers, and illustrators; scheduling; resumes and portfolios; taxes; and marketing of graphic design services. Lecture/field work.

TitleBlock: VSCM 478  Graphic Design Seminar: Advanced Techniques 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An exploration for the subtleties that distinguish excellence in graphic design print, web and motion venues.  Selections include: Advanced Typography and Electronic Portfolio.

TitleBlock: VSCM 479  Graphic Design Seminar: Advanced Media 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An exploration of advanced media development in Graphic Design as relevancy and currency demands.  Selections include: Illustration I and II and Bookmaking.

TitleBlock: VSCM 480   [WI] Graphic Design Seminar: Design Perceptions 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An exploration of how graphic designers use visual communications tools and how audiences perceive them.  Selections include: History of Visual Propaganda and Deconstruction Advertising.  May be repeated for credit if topic varies.

TitleBlock: VSCM 482  Graphic Design for Cultural Organizations 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students experience firsthand how design can enhance the mission of cultural organizations, what it takes to develop innovative outreach programs, and how to apply for grants to achieve their creative endeavors.  Projects assigned will be live, and will be conducted in and outside of the classroom.

TitleBlock: VSCM 485  Annual Report Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Development and analysis of the corporate annual report as a graphic design concept and as a developed marketing tool.

TitleBlock: VSCM 496  Senior Capstone 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Requires each student to define a problem and set a goal and strategies, develop a concept, and carry out a solution. Divides time among research, design, thematic development, and final presentation. Requires instructor approval of study.

TitleBlock: VSCM I199  Independent Study in Graphic Design 0.0-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

TitleBlock: IDM 100  Introduction to Web Development 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This is an entry level course for non-interactive digital media majors that introduces students to the process of managing online content as well as how to define the presentation styles and interaction modes for the user through the use of a content management system.

TitleBlock: IDM 101  History of Web Development 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores all aspects of web development including the foundations of web technologies, formulation of web standards and how the individual web surfer's wants and needs have changed over time. Also discussed will be ground-breaking websites and the evolution of interface design for the web.

TitleBlock: IDM 211  User Interface Design I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course covers the design, prototyping, and evaluation of graphical user interfaces by exploring topics like human capabilities, input technologies, heuristic evaluation, and design methods, principles and rules. We will learn how to design aesthetically pleasing user interfaces, covering important design principles (learnability, visibility, error prevention, efficiency, and visual design) and the human capabilities that motivate them (including perception, motor skills, color vision, attention, and human error).

TitleBlock: IDM 212  User Interface Design II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course builds upon the topics covered in User Interface Design I by exploring advanced topics of graphical user interface design for desktop, mobile, and touch screen devices.

TitleBlock: IDM 213  Interaction Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is a study of interaction design. You will explore principles, patterns and process for interaction design, define the structure and behavior of interactive systems and how these can be used to create meaningful relationships between people and the products and services that they use.

TitleBlock: IDM 215  User Experience Design I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: In this course, students learn to identify and implement the elements required to create incredible digital experiences. Through the application of user-centered design practices, students will develop predictive and enjoyable designs based on a holistic consideration of users’ experience. Topics covered in this course include brand personality, research strategies, content strategy, information architecture, and usability.

TitleBlock: IDM 216  User Experience Design II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on taking prototypes from User Design I and creating fully functioning web apps. Students will create and execute a full production pipeline and learn to incorporate User Design practices along the way.

TitleBlock: IDM 221  Web Design I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is a comprehensive overview of the design, creation, delivery and maintenance of functional, standards-based content on the Internet. Students will learn the aesthetics of web design alongside the underlying markup languages. They will critically evaluate web design quality, learn how to create and maintain quality web sites, and learn about accessibility and web design standards, and why they are important.

TitleBlock: IDM 222  Web Design II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course builds upon the topics covered in Web Authoring I by exploring advanced web development topics and current industry best practices.

TitleBlock: IDM 231  Scripting for Interactive Digital Media I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores modern client-side scripting languages that interact with the user, control the browser, communicate asynchronously, and alter document content and functionality.
CourseName: Scripting for Interactive Digital Media I

TitleBlock: IDM 232  Scripting for Interactive Digital Media II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores modern server-side technologies for Internet based delivery of dynamic content that connect to and manipulate database content. Students learn how to build interactive, data-driven products.
CourseName: Scripting for Interactive Digital Media II

TitleBlock: IDM 240  Interactive Graphics 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: In this course, students learn how to use modern development techniques to create responsive and scalable two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and dynamic animation. Topics include styling and transforming vector graphics, raster graphics, and text where the implementation takes future growth into consideration.

TitleBlock: IDM 241  Microinteractions 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: In this course, students learn to identify and implement the elements required to create incredible digital experiences. Through the application of user-experience design practices, students will develop predictive and enjoyable interactive designs based on a holistic consideration of users’ experience. Topics covered in this course include brand personality, content strategy, information architecture, and usability.

TitleBlock: IDM 245  Web Game Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Examines multimedia-authoring tools used to create interactive games. Students learn real world production techniques as they master advanced game design concepts.

TitleBlock: IDM 250  Content Management Systems 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students set up a content management system and develop a custom theme. Includes project planning, organizing and maintaining a quality code base.

TitleBlock: IDM 311  User Interface Design for Immersive Media 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores the nature of user interface design when applied to immersive media hardware, including Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality headsets.
CourseName: User Interface Design for Immersive Media

TitleBlock: IDM 331  WebVR 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores ways to deliver virtual reality experiences via a web browser.

TitleBlock: IDM 361  Interactive App Design I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Focuses on creating user experiences optimized for mobile devices. Students learn to build unique web applications that take advantage modern mobile capabilities. Special consideration is given to limited screen real estate, low bandwidth Internet access, no Internet access, and touch screen devices.

TitleBlock: IDM 362  Interactive App Design II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course builds upon the topics covered in Mobile Interactive Design I by exploring how to convert web-based applications into cross-platform native applications for mobile devices. Special consideration is given to incorporating functionality that is currently unavailable in web-based applications.

TitleBlock: IDM 363  Interactive App Design III 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores ways to deliver and test native mobile application prototypes using IDE’s (integrated Development Environments).

TitleBlock: IDM 364  Interactive App Design IV 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Learn how to build and test dynamic web application prototypes using event driven JavaScript languages.

TitleBlock: IDM 371  Interactive Digital Media Workshop I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores the developing or redesigning a successful interactive digital experience. Students work in team environments to analyze project requirements, develop a strategy for development, and utilize their design skills to present their findings to the client.

TitleBlock: IDM 372  Interactive Digital Media Workshop II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course builds upon the topics covered in Interactive Digital Media Workshop II by continuing to work in a team environment to building a high-fidelity interactive digital media prototype with a focus on usability testing.

TitleBlock: IDM 381  Experimental Interactive Technologies 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on researching new innovations in experimental digital media technologies.

TitleBlock: IDM 382  Internet of Things 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course uses an open approach to enable quick and seamless interactions with physical objects and locations via web protocols.

TitleBlock: IDM 399  Independent Project in Interactive Digital Media 0.5-6.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Supervised planning and execution of a project in the area of Interactive Digital Media.
CourseName: Independent Project in Interactive Digital Media 0.5-

TitleBlock: IDM 401  Professional Practices in Interactive Digital Media 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will provide a broad overview of the practices of all areas included in the fields related to interactive digital media, including: organizational structure and roles, client communication and creative process, needs assessment, brief writing, brainstorming, concept development, pitches, pricing, proposals and presentations.
CourseName: Professional Practices in Interactive Digital Media

TitleBlock: IDM 402  Validating Product Ideas 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will teach you how to design, implement, and measure multichannel experiences with greater impact for customers, businesses, and society.

TitleBlock: IDM 417  User Research Methodologies 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Understanding the user is the fundamental backbone of User Experience Design. This course will teach students how to construct, implement and analyze user interviews in a way that will allow them to gain deep insights into their target audience.

TitleBlock: IDM 418  Storytelling for User Experience Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will learn how to use stories to understand the user, his/her goals and objectives, explain research, and describe design concepts.

TitleBlock: IDM I399  Independent Study in Interactive Digital Media 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
CourseName: Independent Study in Interactive Digital Media 0.5-1

TitleBlock: INTR 160  Visualization I: Computer Imaging 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An introductory course that explores the use of proprietary computer applications for communications and the preparation of visual materials in Interior Design.  The course introduces and reinforces classic design principles for expert visual communication of ideas through digital techniques from an Interior Design perspective.

TitleBlock: INTR 200  History of Modern Architecture and Interiors 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers development of modern architecture and interiors in the 19th and 20th centuries. Develops a vocabulary for discussing architecture; an understanding of how various factors affect design; and a familiarity with names, movements, and buildings that are part of historical development.
CourseName: History of Modern Architecture and Interiors

TitleBlock: INTR 211  Textiles for Interiors 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is a comprehensive introduction to textiles and their use in the interior design profession.

TitleBlock: INTR 220  Visualization II: Orthographic 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores design communication skills through hand drawing and model building exercises.  Orthographic drawing skills are developed through investigation of plan, section, elevation and three dimensional drawings.

TitleBlock: INTR 225  Environmental Design Theory 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course introduces design students to the relationship between people and the build environment.  Understanding how people perceive, interact with, and are affected by their surroundings through readings and design exercieses make evident the significance of the psychological, pyshicological, social and cultural concepts of environmental behavior as an integral part of the designed environment.

TitleBlock: INTR 231  Structure 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Investigates structure as an organizing principle in design by man and nature. Explores the basic objective and subjective relationships between form and function. Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 232  Interior Studio I 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Primary spatial course. Involves conscious recognition of the manipulability of space or spaces within a given volume and small-scale environmental orientation. Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 233  Interior Studio II 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers diagramming program requirements, designing for complex spatial requirements with an awareness of building systems (e.g., partitions, heating/ventilating/cooling, lighting), and furniture. Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 241  Visualization III: Digital 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An intensive introduction to two and three dimensional drawing and visualization through the computer.  This course explores orthographic and perspective drawing conventions and techniques from a digital perspective.

TitleBlock: INTR 245  Visualization IV: 3D Modeling 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An intensive introduction to advanced modeling and rendering software.  Students will explore lighting, materiality, advanced form and spatial experience through realistic three-dimensional digital models.

TitleBlock: INTR 250  Interior Materials 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Introduces basic construction materials and how they may be used successfully by the interior designer. Includes sample materials, visual aids, and guest speakers.

TitleBlock: INTR 300   [WI] Visual Culture: Interiors 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Visual Culture: Interiors addresses the interior environment by studying the role history, economics, culture, materials and technological developments, impact decisions made by designers on interior spaces.  While comparing historical context with specific knowledge, this course will enable the student to be a more articulate designer by a comprehensive examination of the interiors. This is a writing intensive course.

TitleBlock: INTR 305   [WI] Visual Culture: Furniture 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An overview of furniture in relationship to interiors, and its influences reaching from the roots of antiquity to the impact of technology in today's products.  It is the study of artifacts from various time periods and cultures in relation to social and political developments, life and work styles, visual arts, and economic influences.

TitleBlock: INTR 310  Sustainability: History, Theory and Critic 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Course examines the meaning and implications of sustainable design to develop an informed interpretation and working assessment of this movement.  Concepts and methodologies are explored through assigned readings, class discussion, feild trips and team research.

TitleBlock: INTR 331  Residential Design Studio 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides experience with extensive real space. Emphasizes recognizing its aesthetic quality and maximizing its potential to meet the requirements of the inhabitants, by stylistic quality and elaboration in the selection and application of furniture finishes and accessories. Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 341  Visualization V: Methods 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An advanced course in visualization for Interior Design.  Hybrid representation strategies and specialized topics in digital and hand rendering will be covered.

TitleBlock: INTR 350  Interior Detailing 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers basic considerations of interior construction and detailing and their application.

TitleBlock: INTR 351  Interior Lighting 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course analyzes human needs and the perceptual responses of both general and special populations. It introduces the lighting design theory and principles and explores methods of creating mood and atmosphere with light. It develops vocabulary, documentation methods and understanding of energy conservation, lighting standards, and safety.

TitleBlock: INTR 410  Collaborative Research in Sustainability 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This cumulative course is the advanced students' opportunity to participate in a collaborative, interdisciplinary team in which the students will be applying sustainable technical and conceptual education in the context of 3rd party competitions, internally defined design challenges or applied research.

TitleBlock: INTR 430  Commercial Design Studio 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers design of institutional-commercial interiors, including space planning, selection of materials and furnishings toward a synthesized environment, and development of specifications. Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 441  Furniture Design 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers design of environmental elements, simultaneous concerns with craftsmanship and the application of materials to ideas, and development of prototypes.

TitleBlock: INTR 442  Hospitality Design Studio 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers design of commercial hospitality interiors, including spatial layout, custom furnishings, lighting, selection of materials, and code requirements.  Includes professionally juried presentations.

TitleBlock: INTR 445  Contract Documentation for Interior Design 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides an understanding of the basic procedures and techniques for the development of construction drawings and furniture documentation. Requires students to use case studies to produce a set of drawings representative of current interior design industry standards.

TitleBlock: INTR 450   [WI] Professional Practice 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys contemporary business methods, practices, and procedures in the operation of a design firm, including legal and ethical implications. Examines these practices through case studies and lectures by design professionals. This is a writing intensive course.

TitleBlock: INTR 451  Interior Systems 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Introduces building systems, mechanical, electrical, ceiling and furniture systems, and their effect on the interior environment.  Includes visual aids and guest speakers.

TitleBlock: INTR 470  Competition Studio 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Competition opportunities from regional to international from professional to philanthropic allow for investigations of diverse contemporary issues surrounding the built environment.  Students work under direction of a faculty member(s) to discuss, explore and develop solutions for entry into noteworthy competitions.

TitleBlock: INTR 491  Senior Project I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Part one of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.

TitleBlock: INTR 492  Senior Project II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Part two of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.

TitleBlock: INTR 493  Senior Project III 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Part three of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.

TitleBlock: MUSC 101  University Chorus 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: A large chorus that studies and performs music of many styles; performs each term. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 102  Chamber Singers 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: A select choir that performs advanced choral repertoire; performs frequently on and off campus. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 103  Naturally Sharp (Vocal Jazz Ensemble) 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Naturally Sharp is a select group of singers, chosen by audition in the fall from the University Chorus.  Naturally Sharp performs vocal jazz repertoire from the past hundred years with a three-piece backup band.  Singers must also be able to do solos.

TitleBlock: MUSC 104  All-College Choir 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: All-College Choir is a non-auditioned, mixed voice ensemble that performs repertoire of various styles, genres and eras - including music of the classical tradition, jazz, spirituals, American musical theater, folk and pop.

TitleBlock: MUSC 105  Concert Band 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs a wide variety of music written for a large band; concerts given each term. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 106  Guitar Ensembles 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small guitar ensemble; concerts given at least twice a year.  May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 107  Jazz Ensembles 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Offers rehearsal, study, and performance of jazz compositions for both large and small ensembles; concerts given on and off campus, sometimes with guest soloists. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 108  Jazztet 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Jazztet is a subset of the larger Jazz Orchestra.  Its size can vary based upon the availability of instrumentation and the desire of the director.  Its purpose is to present jazz music in a small instrumentation format.  Performances are typically part of the greater Jazz Orchestra concerts at the end of each term.

TitleBlock: MUSC 109  University Orchestra 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: This is a full orchestra that performs concert repertoire of various periods from the 18th century to the present day.  Wind, brass, and percussionists must be in the concert band in order to participate.

TitleBlock: MUSC 110  Keyboard Ensembles 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small keyboard ensemble; concerts given at least twice a year.  May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 111  Chamber Music Ensemble 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Various small ensembles performing a variety of music of many periods and styles. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 112  Fusion Band 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small fusion ensemble.  The Fusion Band gives concerts at least twice a year.  May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 113  Percussion Ensembles 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small percussion ensemble.  The ensemble gives concerts at least twice a year.  May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 114  Mediterranean Ensemble 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The Drexel University Mediterranean Ensemble is open to any student with an interest in performing traditional music from the Balkans, the Middle East and Northern Africa. All instruments are welcomed.

TitleBlock: MUSC 115  Gospel Choir 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Performs gospel music drawn from both traditional and contemporary sources. Performance opportunities for both singers and instrumentalists. Concerts given on and off campus each term. May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 116  Pep Band 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Pep Band is a group of roughly forty-five student musicians primarily from the concert band.  The purpose of the Pep Band is to support the Drexel Dragons basketball team and play from the bleachers at home games as well as travel to tournaments.

TitleBlock: MUSC 117  Rock Ensemble 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Rock Ensemble is an ensemble where students have the opportunity to gain experience working as a group rehearsing, arranging, organizing, recording, and ultimately performing songs in the rock/pop/contemporary genres. By choosing music that is both of high quality and varied, students have a unique opportunity to develop a strong work ethic while being exposed to various musical challenges.

TitleBlock: MUSC 118  Chamber Music: Strings 0-1 Credits
DescriptionBlock: MUSC 118 forms its participants into various sized string groups from trios and quartets to octets.  The repertoire spans music of the classical tradition and beyond, from the modern day back to the 17th century.  These small groups will perform as part of a larger chamber recital at the end of each term.

TitleBlock: MUSC 120  Music Fundamentals 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Music Fundamentals teaches students essential skills and knowledge relating to Western music.  Focus is placed on ear training and core music theory concepts.  This course perfectly compliments any student’s musical playing ability, beginning to advanced, and is essential to further musical development.

TitleBlock: MUSC 121  Music Theory I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: MUSC 121 covers the foundations of: notation, major/minor scales and keys, intervals, chord construction, phrase construction, small forms, and basic techniques of harmonizing a melody.  The methodology centers on analysis combined with application.

TitleBlock: MUSC 122  Music Theory II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: MUSC 122 covers: texture and textural reduction, chromatic harmony, modulation, and large forms. This is a continuation of MUSC 121 and provides more depth into the topics of that course as well as offers advanced material. The methodology combines musical analysis with application.

TitleBlock: MUSC 123  Music Theory III 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Covers a variety of musical forms from binary and rondo to sonata-allegro, including both sectional and continuous forms, to gain an understanding of the relationship between form and the materials of music. Studies form both in relation to its historical evolution and in terms of its generative role in the creation of music.

TitleBlock: MUSC 124  Jazz Theory 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Jazz Theory introduces musical concepts and skills as they pertain to this specific style of music. The material discussed is foundational knowledge for jazz composition, arranging, and improvisation. Therefore, this course is suitable for students interested in jazz performance or composition.

TitleBlock: MUSC 125  Ear Training I 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Introduces the basics of ear training and sight singing.

TitleBlock: MUSC 126  Ear Training II 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Continues MUSC 125.

TitleBlock: MUSC 127  Ear Training III 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Continues MUSC 126.

TitleBlock: MUSC 130  Introduction to Music 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides an introduction to music in the European classical tradition, including elements of melody, harmony, rhythm, texture, structure, history, and principal composers. Emphasizes listening with understanding.

TitleBlock: MUSC 134  Mambo, Samba, Salsa, and More 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course introduces the various Latin American musical traditions, as well as their historical contexts, evolution, inter-connectivity and current importance.

TitleBlock: MUSC 152  Survey of Songwriting 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will examine the art and craft of songwriting. Students will listen to and analyze many examples from folk and popular music, from the 1930’s through to the present day. Students will use this knowledge, as well as that of basic music fundamentals, to compose a song at the end of the term.

TitleBlock: MUSC 190  Class Piano I 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on piano.

TitleBlock: MUSC 191  Class Guitar I 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on guitar.

TitleBlock: MUSC 192  Class Percussion I 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on percussion.

TitleBlock: MUSC 193  Class Voice I 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction in voice.

TitleBlock: MUSC 194  Class Bass I 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Class Bass I uses group instruction to teach basic performance skills and techniques on electric bass guitar and upright bass.

TitleBlock: MUSC 195  Class Bass II 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Class Bass II uses group instruction to teach advanced performance skills and techniques on electric bass guitar and upright bass.

TitleBlock: MUSC 196  Jazz Class Piano 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will learn the fundamentals in jazz piano playing by studying the melodic, harmonic and rhythmic aspects associated with jazz. Students will learn how to read, “lead sheets” and improvise over modal and standard chord changes.

TitleBlock: MUSC 229  Modern Arranging Techniques 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Modern Arranging Techniques.  Discusses the capabilities and ranges of varying instruments.  Students study modern arranging techniques utilizing strategies and standard music material.

TitleBlock: MUSC 231  Music History I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys and analyzes compositions from antiquity through the Baroque period in European music history.

TitleBlock: MUSC 232  Music History II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course surveys and analyzes compositions from the Romantic Era through the 21st Century in Western music history.

TitleBlock: MUSC 234  The Beatles 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will examine the cultural phenomena of The Beatles from their early history as a band through the end of their regular collaboration in 1970. While The Beatles have been examined in many different ways, this course will concentrate on their productivity as a rock band through the single pop song, the pop album, and film. It will also serve to provide a more in depth study of the group and their influence on other popular culture.

TitleBlock: MUSC 235   [WI] History of Film Music 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course surveys film music from the silent film era to the present. Topics will include the composers of the genre, the changing musical styles through the decades, and the techniques used by film composers.

TitleBlock: MUSC 236  Rock Music Through the Mid-60s 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys rock music from its roots through the mid-60s.

TitleBlock: MUSC 238  Rock Music Since the Mid-60s 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys rock music from the mid-60s through the mid-90s.

TitleBlock: MUSC 241  Private Lesson 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Weekly private music lessons on an instrument or voice as indicated by the section number. Lessons are fifty minutes per week. The specific day and time is mutually agreed upon by the instructor and the student. Musical style, level of ability, and learning objectives are individually based. Students are encouraged to contact the instructor if they have questions. Students are charged a lab fee every term they register.

TitleBlock: MUSC 249  Digital Music Composition 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Digital Music Composition teaches students how to compose music intended to be produced by a computer and related to software, opposed to composing for acoustic instruments.  Students will learn how to use specific music software and explore contemporary compositional techniques.

TitleBlock: MUSC 252  Music Composition 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Music Composition engages students in writing music for ensembles ranging from solo performer to large ensemble.   Techniques of the common practice period as well as modernist harmonic techniques will be introduced and applied.  Live performance of student projects will be provided and is an important feature of the course.

TitleBlock: MUSC 290  Class Piano II 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Class Piano II is a continuation of Class Piano I. By the end of the term students will be able to perform a number of simple songs, play several scales and chord progressions, and have basic note reading skills.

TitleBlock: MUSC 291  Class Guitar II 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Class Guitar II is a continuation of Class Guitar I. In this course students continue to work on note reading in first position, develop rhythmic skills and reading ability in different keys, learn movable barred chords and power chords, and learn basic finger picking technique.

TitleBlock: MUSC 300  Improvisation 0.0-3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides study and practice of various improvisatory styles in music. Includes classroom lectures, listening, and solo and ensemble performance.

TitleBlock: MUSC 323  Songwriting 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Addresses basic songwriting techniques including form, melody, rhythm, lyrics, and production.  Projects are required.

TitleBlock: MUSC 331  World Musics 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys various musical traditions from around the world in their cultural contexts. Includes selected music from Africa, the Americas, Europe, South Asia, Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia, West Asia, and Oceania.

TitleBlock: MUSC 333  Afro-American Music USA 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Examines the African heritage and related New World forms outside the United States. Covers work songs, spirituals, blues, folk music, ragtime, gospel, rhythm and blues, jazz, etc.

TitleBlock: MUSC 336  History of Jazz 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Surveys the music popularly known as jazz from before 1900 through the stylistic changes and trends of the 20th century. Covers precursors, early jazz, big bands, bebop, the new music, etc.

TitleBlock: MUSC 338   [WI] American Popular Music 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Examines popular music (dances, marches, ragtime, jazz, musical comedy, movie music, swing, rock, etc.) from Colonial times to the present, with cultural-historical contexts. This is a writing intensive course.

TitleBlock: MUSC 341  Advanced Applied Music 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Weekly private applied music instruction at the advanced level.  Fee requirement.  May be repeated for credit.

TitleBlock: MUSC 342  Applied Music-Recital 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will present a public recital featuring significant solo repertoire.  Repertoire choices for recital must be made through the Applied Music instructor.

TitleBlock: MUSC 495  Directed Studies in Music 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides supervised individual study of special subjects in music. May be repeated for credit.  Department permission required.

TitleBlock: MUSC I199  Independent Study in MUSC 0.0-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

TitleBlock: MIP 132  Survey of the Recording Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course offers a comprehensive overview of the history of the Recording Industry plus an in-depth examination of the key changes that have affected the world of the Industry over the past 25 years. Marketing, Promotion, Branding, Music Streaming, Touring, Social Media development, and artist development will be covered.

TitleBlock: MIP 133  Digital Audio Workstations I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will provide students with a basic understanding of Digital Audio Workstation theory and practice as it relates to content creation through Music Instruments Digital Interface ( M.I.D.I.) sequencing. In addition to M.I.D.I. sequencing, students will be introduced to editing, and mixing.

TitleBlock: MIP 161  Copyrights in the Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is an in-depth exploration of what, how, when and where intellectual property exists in the music industry, with a particular emphasis on the role that copyrights play.

TitleBlock: MIP 170  Radio Management 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students learn about the growth and development of radio through the 20th century to today, including current challenges and new technologies, programming and marketing techniques, payola, organizational structure, corporate consolidation, the F.C.C., podcasting, satellite, and internet radio.  Students also create their own radio stations and formats.

TitleBlock: MIP 179  Introduction to Sound Recording 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Introduces the art of sound recording, including fundamentals of sound, sound capture, acoustic environment, recording devices, and the recording studio. Stakeholders, such as engineers, producers, and technicians are discussed.

TitleBlock: MIP 227  Listening Techniques 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: Students will develop critical listening skills needed for all aspects of music production including commercial arranging, tracking, and mixing.

TitleBlock: MIP 233  Digital Audio Workstations II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on Digital Audio Workstation techniques used in modern audio production. This course will provide students with a basic understanding of Digital Audio Workstation theory of operation, system setup and troubleshooting, audio recording, editing, and “in the box” mixing.

TitleBlock: MIP 262  Trademarks and Patents in the Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is an in-depth continuation of the exploration of what, how, when and where intellectual property exists in the music industry, with a further emphasis on the use of trademarks and patents in the music and music software industries.
CourseName: Trademarks and Patents in the Music Industry

TitleBlock: MIP 263  Media Promotion 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students learn about the procedures and mechanisms used to promote music and music-related content through various media forms, primarily radio and video, and through any new media forms recently or futuristically discovered.

TitleBlock: MIP 270  Live Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Course examines the basic concepts, key terms and roles of all essential players for both the venue management and touring and concert promotion industry and the relationships between venues, booking agents, tour managers and media.

TitleBlock: MIP 276  Sound Recording for Business Concentration 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Sound recording techniques are presented to provide Music Industry Business Concentration students with basic recording competency through practical application. Students are required to create several recordings through projects that require teamwork and self-analysis.

TitleBlock: MIP 279  Sound Recording I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Basic sound recording procedures are presented with an emphasis on microphone techniques, signal-flow, and session workflow. Requires students to create several multitrack recordings, including editing and mixing.

TitleBlock: MIP 293   [WI] Survey of Music Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course analyzes various music recordings, including the genres of jazz, pop, R&B, and rock, from the modern recording era (1930’s to the present) and discusses the production techniques used to create them.

TitleBlock: MIP 318  Music Merchandising 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students work in interdisciplinary groups with Design and Merchandising students to create a comprehensive merchandise extension program including product selection, production, distribution and promotion within the context of the artists' overall brand package.

TitleBlock: MIP 331  Music Venues and Concerts 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will learn how to operate a music venue by learning how to book talent, market and promote, staff and hire personnel, create visibility, establish a long-term vision for the music venue.

TitleBlock: MIP 333  Digital Audio Workstations III 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on advanced Digital Audio Workstation techniques used in modern recording production with an emphasis on audio editing. Sound replacement, pitch correction, alignment, audio quantization, and editing proficiency are covered.

TitleBlock: MIP 336  Contracts and Legal Issues in the Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores contractual agreements and the legal issues affecting the music industry today, such as free speech in radio and music lyrics, rights of publicity for recording artists, fair use and piracy, as well as the various standard agreements in common use in the music and recording industries.
CourseName: Contracts and Legal Issues in the Music Industry

TitleBlock: MIP 338  Audio Seminar 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students present Extra Curricular recording projects to the instructor and fellow students for an in-class critique. The in-class critique will give the student direct feedback on their creative work and allow them to compare their work against the work of their peers. The production critiques will be moderated by the instructor and grades will be assessed based on in-class participation and presentations.

TitleBlock: MIP 341  Touring and Booking 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Educates student about the Live Performance revenue stream in the music industry, encompassing tour management, tour planning and implementation, concert promotion agreements, insurance issues and revenue breakdowns.

TitleBlock: MIP 358  Electronic Music Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is a holistic approach to electronic music production through the study of its history and hands on digital audio workstations techniques.

TitleBlock: MIP 361  Music Publishing 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores the fundamental responsibilities of a music publisher including reviewing, evaluating, marketing, licensing, monetizing, representing and protecting original music, as well as the rights of songwriters and related content creators. Students will discover how music publishing is a crucial element of support in a thriving music industry and will learn how music publishers build value for their creative clients.

TitleBlock: MIP 365  Cities of Music and Culture 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is designed to give students an introductory insight and understanding of the music industry in the chosen location of the class. This class is a Study Tour.

TitleBlock: MIP 366  Music Supervision 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will be introduced to the creative and administrative elements of music supervision including sourcing, evaluating, licensing, and placing music into visual productions.

TitleBlock: MIP 374  Entrepreneurship in the Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will learn how to devise, conceive, create and implement a music industry-related business through the drafting of a business plan.  This course is team-driven and will involve student discussions and critique.

TitleBlock: MIP 375   [WI] Marketing and Promo in Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is designed for students to understand marketing & promotion in the music industry and provide insight into the concepts of marketing and the tactics employed by labels, independent agents, and artists in the marketplace. Students will acquire the skills to assemble comprehensive, integrated marketing strategies that accompany a successful marketing campaign. This is a writing intensive course.
CourseName: [WI] Marketing and Promo in Music Industry

TitleBlock: MIP 376  MAD Dragon Music Group 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: MAD Dragon Music Group is designed to immerse students in the world of the independent music business and includes all of the professor led, student operated enterprises that create, organize and administer MAD Dragon Music Group projects.

TitleBlock: MIP 379  Sound Recording II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An advanced examination of current state of the art sound recording techniques. Special attention is paid to concert recording, digital and analog mixing techniques, advanced compression and equalization techniques, and time-based processing. Research methods in sound are introduced.

TitleBlock: MIP 381  Audio for Video 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will introduce the student to the technological and creative aspects of creating post-production audio for visual media.

TitleBlock: MIP 382  Scoring to Picture 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will expand the students' ability to create and produce an original score for an audio/visual element, drawing upon their creative and technological skills.

TitleBlock: MIP 384  Synthesis and Sampling 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This is an advanced course focusing on the theory and operation of hardware and virtual synthesizers and digital audio samplers.  Students learn how to identify and manipulate the various parameters of synthesis and sampling devices.

TitleBlock: MIP 386  Commercial Music Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An examination of the various ways that music is composed and used in television advertising, industries, trailers/promos for film, television, and radio, including bumpers and station ids.

TitleBlock: MIP 387  Studio Maintenance 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Introduces the student to basic maintenance and troubleshooting techniques used in the modern recording studio. Basic electronic components, cabling, soldering skills, audio measurements, and equipment calibration are emphasized.

TitleBlock: MIP 388  Music and Audio Freelancing 2.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will gain an understanding of how to prepare for and develop a career as a freelancer in the music and/or audio industries.  They will learn how to develop career goals and a plan of action, create a basic professional website, and learn the basic financial, business, and marketing practices of a freelancer.

TitleBlock: MIP 389  Sound Reinforcement 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course covers all aspects of sound reinforcement for live performances, including system design, equipment usage, and acoustical concerns. The course uses both lecture and hands-on components for greater student understanding.

TitleBlock: MIP 390  Video Game Music and Audio 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The objective of this course is to give students a well-rounded understanding of the state of contemporary video game music and audio; how the game development process works; the evolution of game audio, and how to approach the creation of video game music and audio.

TitleBlock: MIP 391  Analog Recording 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This class enables students to practice the art of analog recording, editing and mixing. It puts in perspective the concepts, tools, and techniques of studio production that can be taken for granted in the digital domain. The constraints and aesthetic choices that are magnified by the analog format are very important parts of a holistic music production curriculum.

TitleBlock: MIP 392  Music Production Master Class 1.0 Credit
DescriptionBlock: A guest music producer and his team will share their knowledge of record production. Students will learn both technical and business aspects of professional record production and will be assigned projects helping them develop a high level of expertise and professionalism.

TitleBlock: MIP 394  Big Data In The Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course offers a comprehensive overview of collecting, analyzing, and understanding all aspects of Big Data research in the music industry. By intensive studies of the analytics of the data flow and how that information is used, this course will show students how to interpret the ebb and flow of the music business.
CourseName: Big Data In The Music Industry

TitleBlock: MIP 395  Digital Revenue & Creative Destruction 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will study the disruption, destruction and transformation of the music industry business model through the lens of entrepreneurial innovation in the post-Napster era. This course is team-driven and will involve extensive student discussions and critique.

TitleBlock: MIP 396  Global Recording Business 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is designed to give students a global perspective of the recording business. Students will research individual markets and compare and contrast them in order to evaluate business conditions and consider future economic prospects.

TitleBlock: MIP 426  Global Trends in the Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores how the music, arts and entertainment industries operate and interact with a global perspective. Students will examine the unique attributes and different cultural and artistic components of global music industry centers with emphasis on "placemaking" factors, government-support models, economic landscape, market trends, chart history, deal types/income streams, hitmakers and moguls, and specific genres and styles emanating from around the world. Students will gain a greater understanding of how music, entertainment and various media platforms are perceived, supported and commoditized throughout the world.
CourseName: Global Trends in the Music Industry

TitleBlock: MIP 433  Digital Audio Workstations IV 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course focuses on advanced Digital Audio Workstation techniques used in modern audio production. This course will explore trends in DAW technology and showcase emerging production techniques used in the creation of modern music.

TitleBlock: MIP 443  Entertainment Contracts I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course encompasses drafting and negotiating the most common types of agreements in the music industry.

TitleBlock: MIP 467  Artist Representation 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Students will gain an historical perspective on the evolving role of the Manager from an entrepreneurial perspective. The class examines the core components that comprise an artist's professional team. The course will explore and analyze the central role that managers in particular, but also, attorneys, agents, business managers, services firms, record labels and other entities each play in representing, developing, and supervising the artist’s overall business and brand.

TitleBlock: MIP 468  Music Industry E-Commerce 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course explores the inner workings of commerce in the music industry as it occurs in the Internet.   The student gains an understanding of how to market and promote websites, utilize social networking sites and how digital services for the industry can serve the label, artist and/or publishing company.

TitleBlock: MIP 477  Music Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The students in this class learn contemporary music production techniques through a combination of lecture, demonstration and independent work.

TitleBlock: MIP 481  Mixing and Mastering 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The art of mixing and mastering music are covered in depth.  This is an advanced audio engineering course that will focus on the mixing and mastering process. Proper equipment usage, methods, formats, and production goals are covered.

TitleBlock: MIP 491  Senior Project in Music Industry 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Senior Project is a thesis course in which student groups engage over the three quarters of senior year in intensive research on a topic selected by a jury among individual proposals.   The thesis will result in some form of publishable material.  The student will present their thesis to a jury in their final quarter of senior year.

TitleBlock: MIP 495  Directed Studies in Music Industry 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides supervised individual study of special topics in the music industry.   Departmental permission required.

TitleBlock: MIP I199  Independent Study in Music Industry Program 0.0-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

TitleBlock: PHTO 110  Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Lecture-laboratory course in black and white photography. With a combination of lectures, assignments and group critiques, students learn to see photographically through an exploration of the basic tools, techniques and aesthetics of photography. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

TitleBlock: PHTO 140  Digital Photography I 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The objective of this course is to give you an introduction to the technical skills necessary to use computers, equipment, and software as a means of visually communicating your photographic ideas.

TitleBlock: PHTO 141  Digital Photographic Post Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is an introduction to the manipulation and output of files using Photoshop and Lightroom. Skills acquired include working with RAW files, density, contrast and color correction, basic retouching, compositing of image, type and color elements along with special effects and output via inkjet printer. A digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required that is capable of shooting in RAW file format.

TitleBlock: PHTO 210  Intermediate Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Continues the aesthetic and technical investigations of black and white photography begun in PHTO 110 through a mix of lectures, slide discussions, analytical and creative projects, and group critiques. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or higher is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

TitleBlock: PHTO 230  Color Photography for Non-Majors 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course will introduce students to the foundations of color photography. It is a lecture-laboratory course that combines the visual, technical, and communicative properties of color photography with comprehensive color digital workflow experience. Students will begin to master the techniques of properly color balancing their prints and develop a sense of how to use color. It is important to grasp the foundations of color photography, but it is equally important to understand the aesthetic implications that using color entails.

TitleBlock: PHTO 231  Color Photography 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An introduction to the aesthetics and technology of color photography.  There is an emphasis on color composition and theory. Class includes a variety of color processes, utilizing analog/film and digital materials.

TitleBlock: PHTO 233  Large Format Photography 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides a thorough exploration of large-format camera techniques and large-format film exposure/development techniques including the zone system. Introduces the aesthetic of the large-format black-and-white photograph and expands the student's vision of the potential of the photographic image.

TitleBlock: PHTO 234  Studio Photography 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Introduces professional studio photography practices.  Continues utilization of the digital camera.  Examines artifical lighting techniques and provides context for exploration of the studio as a creative photographic environment.

TitleBlock: PHTO 236  Photojournalism 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Approaches the subject of photojournalism through lectures on its history and current practices and through application. Considers the documentary genre of photography in general.

TitleBlock: PHTO 240  Digital Photography II 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Explores the digital image within the context of photographic practice. Examines current capabilities and future potentials in image capture, manipulation, output, and dissemination. Projects include utilization of image-manipulation programs, direct digital cameras, and hybrid film/digital approaches. Addresses aesthetic, conceptual, and professional issues.

TitleBlock: PHTO 253  Fine Black & White Printing 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Explores the aesthetic of the fine black-and-white print, including issues of print scale, tonality, surface quality, toning, and archival techniques. Uses zone-system analysis to optimize the relationship of the negative and the print.

TitleBlock: PHTO 275   [WI] History of Photography I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides an overview of the history of photography from 1839 to approximately 1930, including technological developments, aesthetic trends, theoretical and philosophical understandings, and effects on society and culture at large. This is a writing intensive course.

TitleBlock: PHTO 276   [WI] History of Photography II 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides an overview of the history of photography from approximately 1930 to the present, including technological developments, aesthetic trends, theoretical and philosophical understandings, and effects on society and culture at large.

TitleBlock: PHTO 291  Internship 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Incorporates a nonpaying internship in the field of photography for academic credit. An initial informational sheet on the internship and a final paper on the experience are required.  May be repeated for credit.  Department permission required.

TitleBlock: PHTO 334  Advanced Studio Photography 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: An advanced studio photography class that will teach the student the workflow associated with high-end digital studio capture.  The class will also cover various advanced studio lighting techniques.  The development of a personal portfolio of work produced in the studio will be required by all students.

TitleBlock: PHTO 335  Portraiture 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is devoted to the development of a single project.  The course will deal in depth with issues of format, lighting and composition.  The course will address ethical and legal matters in photographic portraiture.  An overview of the history of photographic portrait will be covered.

TitleBlock: PHTO 336  Assignment Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Assignment is simply said to be photography that supports the written word, which may be either news or advertising, article photographs, advertisements, or the cover of a magazine. The purpose of this course is to teach students how to stand out from the photographic crowd by injecting personal style.

TitleBlock: PHTO 340  Digital Photography III 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This class will build on intermediate Photoshop skills while exploring the new field of building a photographic image by using more than one frame or multiple elements.  Students will be expected to produce a body of work using the skills learned.  Large format printing will be stressed.

TitleBlock: PHTO 361  Advanced Photography 4.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Extends study and experimentation in studio, color, and historical photography. Examines non-silver and non-traditional photographic technologies.

TitleBlock: PHTO 392  Junior Project in Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

TitleBlock: PHTO 399  Independent Study In Photography 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Provides individualized study in photography in a specialized area. May be repeated for credit.  Department permission required.

TitleBlock: PHTO 451  Photography and Business 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Seminar course with invited professionals from the photographic and business fields. Helps prospective photographers understand legal aspects of photography, freelance business practices, and potential employment possibilities and expectations.

TitleBlock: PHTO 452   [WI] History of Contemporary Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The course will focus on aesthetic and conceptual development in contemporary photographic practice.  Through lectures, field trips and in-class discussions, students will learn concepts and visual trends employed in photography since 1970.  Topics covered include 19th and 20th century influences, multi-cultural interpretation of genres, new approaches to representation of self.

TitleBlock: PHTO 453  Photography Production 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The objective of this course is to introduce prospective photographers to commercial production practices.  Topics covered will include the definition and marketing of personal style, the varied roles of vendors and clients, interpreting layouts and concepts, and approaches to commercial production.

TitleBlock: PHTO 455  Landscape Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This class is designed to explore the rich tradition and history of the landscape photograph and how to visually translate the contemporary landscape.

TitleBlock: PHTO 456  Fashion Photography 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The objective of this course is for students to become familiar with both the aesthetics and techniques involved in the production of fashion photographs.  In addition, the history of fashion photography will be covered.

TitleBlock: PHTO 457  Palladium Printing 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This class explores the technical and aesthetic aspects of the 19th century, hand-coated palladium and platinum printing processes. Students will use large format negatives to produce a body of work.  This course will include hand-coating techniques, paper and chemistry options.

TitleBlock: PHTO 458  Advertising Portfolio Development 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: This course is designed to prepare students to enter the commercial market.  Topics covered will include the definition and marketing of personal visual style, identity and cohesion, and contemporary self-promotion practices.

TitleBlock: PHTO 459  Marketing for Photographers 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: The objective of this course is to give students practical skills about marketing, design, and production of materials you will need as a photographer.  Discussions and demonstrations will show you how to use print, web, and other technologies to promote your photography.

TitleBlock: PHTO 492  Senior Thesis in Photography I 3.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

TitleBlock: PHTO 493  Senior Thesis in Photography II 3.0 Credits

DescriptionBlock: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project.  Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

TitleBlock: PHTO T480  Special Topics in Photography 0.5-12.0 Credits
DescriptionBlock: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
